metadata.title: Effects of sintering atmosphere and temperature on structural and magnetic properties of Ni-Cu-Zn ferrite nano-particles_ Magnetic enhancement by a reducing atmosphere

sections.text:
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect
Journal of Magnetism and Magnetic Materials
http://d 0304-88
n Corr E-m ah_gh13
journal homepage: www.elsevier.com/locate/jmmm
Effects of sintering atmosphere and temperature on structural and magnetic properties of Ni-Cu-Zn ferrite nano-particles: Magnetic enhancement by a reducing atmosphere
Ahmad Gholizadeh n, Elahe Jafari School of Physics, Damghan University (DU), Damghan, Islamic Republic of Iran
a r t i c l e i n f o
Article history: Received 5 April 2016 Received in revised form 24 July 2016 Accepted 4 September 2016 Available online 5 September 2016
Keywords: Soft ferrite Ni-Cu-Zn ferrite Nanoparticles Structural and magnetic properties
x.doi.org/10.1016/j.jmmm.2016.09.029 53/& 2016 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
esponding author. ail addresses: gholizadeh@du.ac.ir (A. Gholiza 59@yahoo.com (E. Jafari).
a b s t r a c t
In this work, effects of sintering atmosphere and temperature on structural and magnetic properties of Ni0.3Cu0.2Zn0.5Fe2O4 nanoparticles prepared by citrate precursor method have been studied. The structural characterization of the samples by X-ray powder diffraction and FT-IR spectroscopy is evidence for formation of a cubic structure with no presence of impurity phase. Calculated values of crystallite size and unit cell parameter show an increase with sintering temperature under different atmospheres. Variation of saturation magnetization with sintering temperature and atmosphere can be attributed to change of three factors: magnetic core size, inversion parameter and the change of Fe3þ-ion concentration due to the presence of Fe4þ and Fe2þ ions. The saturation magnetization gradually grows with sintering temperature due to increase of magnetic core size and a maximum 63 emu/g was achieved at 600 °C under carbon monoxide-ambient atmosphere.
& 2016 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Ferrites have been extensively investigated in recent years for their useful electrical and magnetic properties and applications in information storage systems, magnetic bulk cores, magnetic fluids, microwave absorbers and high frequency devices [1,2]. Among the spinel ferrites, nowadays, Ni-Cu-Zn ferrites have been the dominant materials for Multi Layer Chip Capacitors (MLCC) and Multilayer Chip Inductor (MLCI) due to its better magnetic properties at high frequency and low sintering temperature [1–5]. Also, these materials exhibit good electro-magnetic properties at higher frequencies [3]. Lower sintering temperature of Ni-Cu-Zn ferrites results in smaller particles that have a key role for manufacturing increasingly thinner MLCC or MLCI [5]. As the grain size should be no more than one-tenth of the layer thickness, nanoparticles ceramics will be applied in co-firing with lower cost Ag electrodes [5].
Many attempts such as various substitutions, preparation methods and heat treatments have been done to improve the magnetic properties of Ni-Cu-Zn ferrites [1–3,6–14]. It is well known that Ni2þ and Cu2þ have strong preferences for octahedral sites whereas other transition metal ions have weaker preferences
deh),
[12–14]. Nickel ferrite (NiFe2O4) and copper ferrite (CuFe2O4) have an inverse spinel structure with Ni2þ and Cu2þ ions at octahedral B sites and Fe3þ ions are equally distributed at tetrahedral A and octahedral B sites. The ferric ions preferentially fill all of the eight A sites. The remaining eight go onto the B sites, as do the eight Ni2þ ions. The antiferromagnetic interaction orients these eight Fe3þ moments and eight nickel moments antiparallel to the eight Fe3þ moments on the tetrahedral sites. The Fe3þ ion moments will just cancel, but the moments on the nickel ions give rise to an uncompensated moment or magnetization. On the other hand, zinc ferrite (ZnFe2O4) has a normal spinel structure with Zn2þ ions at A sites and Fe3þ ions at B-sites [15]. Also, a possible redistribution of Zn2þ and Fe3þ ions by heat treatment within the tetrahedral/octahedral ionic sites, will be followed by important changes in the magnetic properties [16–18]. The inversion is defined as the fraction of A sites occupied by Fe3þ cations and its value depends on method of preparation and heat treatment effects.
Magnetic properties of the bulk materials differ drastically from the nano-sized materials. Often high sintering temperature is used for synthesizing bulk ferrites via solid state reaction route. Low sintering temperature is required for nano-sized materials as basic requirement. Ni0.3Cu0.2Zn0.5Fe2O4 ferrite, has a mixed spinel structure in which the cation distribution can be represented as ( )[ ]+ + + + + −Zn Fe Ni Cu Fe O0.5 2 0.5 3 0.3 2 0.2 2 1.5 3 4 2 [12–15]. The Fe3þ moments on the tetrahedral sites orient all the octahedral site moments antiparallel to them so that the Fe3þ moments on the tetrahedral sites
neutralize only one-fourth of the octahedral Fe3þ ions. This leaves a large percentage (the other three-fourth) oriented but uncompensated, giving a net magnetic moment, in addition to additional magnetic moment originated from the magnetic M2þ ions, which have also been oriented antiparallel. Some sites may be particularly favorable to certain ions over others at high temperatures but the order of preference at low temperatures is reversed. The site preference can be dependent on temperature [1,3,13].
In this work, Ni0.3Cu0.2Zn0.5Fe2O4 nanoparticles prepared by citrate precursor method were sintered under air-, argon-, carbon monoxide-ambient atmospheres at low temperatures 200, 400, 600 °C. The effects of different sintering atmospheres and temperatures on the redistribution of Zn2þ and Fe3þ ions, the oxidation of Fe atoms in lattice, crystallite sizes, IR bands, saturation magnetization and magnetic core sizes have been studied. Also, we tried to explain the structural and magnetic properties by using reasonable experimental data which has been not investigated so far.

sections.heading: 2.1. Sample preparation
sections.text: The Ni0.3Cu0.2Zn0.5Fe2O4 ferrite was prepared by the citrate precursor method. Firstly, a solution containing appropriate concentrations of metal nitrates Fe(NO3)3 9H2O, Zn(NO3)2 4H2O, Cu (NO3)2 3H2O, Ni(NO3)2 6H2O, and citric acid, equal to the total number of moles of nitrate ions, was evaporated at 50 °C, overnight. The homogeneous sol-like substance subsequently was dried at 80 °C, overnight. Then, the resulting spongy and friable materials were powdered and subsequently sintered separately under air-, argon-, carbon monoxide-ambient atmospheres at temperatures 200, 400, 600 °C for 2 h. For convenience, a list of the abbreviations (F1–F9) is given in Table 1.

sections.heading: 2.2. Materials and physical measurements
sections.text:
All the chemicals were purchased from Merck and used as received ones without further purification. The X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns have been recorded using a Bruker AXS diffractometer D8 ADVANCE with Cu-Kα radiation in the range of 2θ¼20–80° at room temperature (RT). The XRD data were analyzed using a commercial X'pert package and Fullprof program. XRD profile analysis is a simple and powerful method for evaluating the crystallite size and lattice micro-strain. Two factors determine the breadth of Bragg peak including crystallite size-dependent or strain dependent broadening effects, except instrument-dependent effect. Scherrer's equation indicates the broadening of the XRD pattern which is attributed to the crystallite sizeinduced broadening [19].
Table 1 Abbreviation, crystallite sizes and micro-strains, lattice parameter, XRD and experiment

Here, βhkl is the full-width at half-maximum of the diffraction peak (311) located at about 35°. Halder and Wagner have given an approximation to the integral breadth of a Voigt function as [20]:

where βL and βG are the Lorentzian and Gaussian components, respectively. In cases of isotropic line broadening, the information on strain (ε) and the crystallite size (D) of the powders have been obtained from βhkl and planar spacing dhkl via Halder-Wagner (HW) method [20]:

where β β θ λ* = cos /hkl hkl and θ λ* =d 2sin /hkl . Finally, the results of Halder-Wagner method are compared with the Scherrer method.
The FT-IR spectra of samples were recorded in a Perkin-Elmer FT-IR spectrometer in the wave number range of 350–2000 cm 1. The morphology of the samples was studied by the SEM (Philips XL30) analysis. The particle size of F7 was investigated by the TEM (LEO Model 912AB) analysis.
The hysteresis loops at room temperature were carried out in a VSM (7400 Lake Shore). In order to deepen the actual size, shape distribution and state of aggregation of the ferromagnetic particles within the samples and the evolution of the magnetization process at high applied fields were analyzed. Generally, the magnetization curve in high fields can usually be fitted by the empirical formula; law of approach to saturation [21]:
( )( )( ) ( ) χ= − − − + + ( )⎡⎣ ⎤⎦M H M a H b H c H H EH1 / / / 4s 2 3 1/2 where ( )M H and MS are the magnetization at the field H and the saturation magnetization, respectively.

sections.heading: 3.1. Structural and morphology properties
sections.text:
X-ray diffraction patterns of F1–F9 are shown in Fig. 1a. The XRD data were analyzed using both the commercial X'pert High Score package and Fullprof program. Identification of structure type using X'pert package confirms cubic structure in all samples without the presence of impure phases. The XRD pattern of the samples is fitted with the diffraction pattern of a cubic structure Fe3O4 (JCPDS, 74-2399). Results of the Rietveld analysis using Fullprof program indicate that all the diffraction peaks of the XRD pattern for the samples can be quite well indexed to the cubic structure (Fd-3m space group) as shown in Fig. 1b. To perform a
al density, porosity and ratio I220/ I222.
(nm) εH-W*103 (no unit) a (Ǻ) ρXRD (g/cm3) ρexp (gr/cm3) P (%) I220/I222
3 1.33 1.33 8.396 5.358 22.79 3.14 6 0.72 0.72 8.397 5.356 23.28 3.25 5 0.48 0.48 8.402 5.347 23.72 4.51
3.26 3.26 8.390 5.370 28.36 1.43 1.86 1.86 8.398 5.354 28.45 3.15
5 1.49 1.49 8.401 5.348 28.82 3.34 6 2.20 2.20 8.349 5.449 20.48 1.35 2 1.54 1.54 8.376 5.393 28.52 3.44 9 0.70 0.70 8.381 5.387 29.28 4.77
Rietveld refinement, good initial values for lattice parameters are needed. The type of space group is obtained from phase analysis of X'pert package. The derived lattice parameter of the samples is given in Table 1. It should be noted that the values of the unit cell parameter for F7 indicates much lower value with respect to the other samples. Increasing trend of unit cell parameter with increase in temperature is observed for three sintering atmospheres. This trend is higher for the samples sintered under carbon monoxide-ambient atmosphere and is lower for the samples sintered under air ambient atmosphere.
The results of crystallite size and micro-strain of F1-F9 estimated by the Scherrer and H-W methods are summarized in Table 1. In these two methods, the values of βhkl (the full-width at half-maximum of the diffraction peaks) and θ are selected from the results obtained from Rietveld refinement using Fullprof program corresponding to the strongest peaks shown in Fig. 1.
The H-W method supposes that the “crystallite size” profile contributes to the line broadening by a Lorentzian function and the “strain” profile by a Gaussian function. This method shows that the line broadening is essentially isotropic. However, the advantage of H-W method over the Scherrer method is the less weight given to data from reflections at high angles; wherein the precision is usually lower. Crystallite size obtained from the H-W analysis, summarized in Table 1, is more accurate; with all data points touching the fitting line (see Fig. 2). The values of crystallite size obtained from these two methods for F4 and F7 are much less than those for the other samples. Increasing trend of crystallite
size due to re-crystallization and increase of unit cell volume with sintering temperature is observed for all samples. But this trend is higher for the samples sintered under carbon monoxide ambient atmosphere and is lower for the samples sintered under air ambient atmosphere.
However, change in both unit cell dimension (a) and oxygen position parameter (u) leads to alteration in the Fe3þ–O2 –Fe3þ bond angle in octahedral site [18]. These phenomena may be the result of the defects and cation redistribution of the samples. The effects of different sintering temperatures and atmospheres can be observed in cation redistribution and oxygen deficiency of the samples, respectively.
Table 1 shows the mean crystallite size, microstrain, lattice constants and also ratios I220/I222 of F1–F9. The observed increase in lattice constant (a) of Ni0.3Cu0.2Zn0.5Fe2O4 nanoparticles with sintering temperature is interpreted as an indication of the reverse transition of cations into their original sites. As can be seen, the mean crystallite size is growing as the temperature increases and the ratios I220/I440 have increased. This shows that the degree of inversion has been reduced with increasing temperature under different sintering atmospheres [17]. We suggest that the greater tendency for crystallinity in F1 may lead to a less strained surface and surface bonds, than in the case of F4 and F7 (see Table 1). In the case of smaller particles the large ratio of surface to volume creates strains and distortions in the structure close to the surface (see the values of microstrain in Table 1). Hence, for nanoparticles the energy differences between the two situations viz. the trivalent Fe ion occupying either of the A or B sites is expected to be reduced in comparison with the energy difference for these two situations in bulk materials, thus tending to support inversion [16]. With decreasing particle sizes and larger corresponding role of the surface, this tendency (of inversion) therefore appears to become stronger. Also, the only process taking place by sintering of Ni0.3Cu0.2Zn0.5Fe2O4 nanoparticles is gradual recrystallization, which is accompanied by the reduced strain, through disappearance of the induced inversion. This process manifests itself by a gradual narrowing of diffraction peaks and redistribution of their intensities. This would also be consistent with the reduction of inversion in the larger size particles where the surface effects become less important.
There is possible change of Fe3þ to Fe4þ and Fe2þ under sintering atmosphere especially at higher sintering temperatures. This suggests that a low fraction of the B sites of Fe ions is populated as Fe4þ and Fe2þ ions. According to previous studies on ferrites, only the presence of Fe2þ has been emphasized as a
shoulder on FTIR spectra at about 250 cm 1 which is assigned to Fe2þ–O2 octahedral complexes. But, Panda et al. [22] by using synchrotron X-ray powder diffraction (SXRD) and X-ray absorption near edge structure (XANES) spectroscopy confirmed existence of Fe4þ ions in a spinel ferrite sintered under air ambient atmosphere. It should be noted that with increase in temperature, Fe3þ-O2 bond becomes weak and consequently formation of oxygen deficiency is expected on surface of the samples sintered under carbon monoxide ambient atmosphere that can produce Fe2þ ions for the preservation of charge neutralization on the surface. On the other hand, disappearance of the induced inversion with increase in temperature is accompanied with increase of formation of Fe4þ and Fe2þ ions in the samples sintered under airand carbon monoxide-ambient atmospheres, respectively. Therefore, higher and lower increasing trend observed in unit cell parameter and crystallite size for the samples sintered under airand carbon monoxide-ambient atmospheres, respectively, can be also related to higher and lower formation of Fe4þ and Fe2þ ions. These findings are in accordance with the refined unit cell parameter obtained from the Rietveld method using Fullprof program (see Table 1). However, a correlation with the magnetic data is necessary, as will be discussed later.
The X-ray density ( ρXRD) of prepared samples was calculated using this formula:
ρ = ( )M Na8 / 5XRD 3
where M is the molecular weight of sample and N is the Avogadro's number. The bulk density (ρexp) of the disc shaped pellet was calculated by considering dimensions and weight of the sample [3]:
ρ π= ( )mass r/ t 6exp 2
where r and t are the radius and thickness of the pellets, respectively. The decreasing trend of the ρXRD and ρexp densities with higher temperature is observed in three atmospheres but ρXRD, is higher than the ρexp, for all the samples (see Table 1). The nature of variation of ρXRD supports the variation in the lattice parameter. The difference between values of ρexp and ρXRD data may be attributed to the porosity originated from the sintering process. The porosity (P) was calculated according to the following equation:
ρ ρ= − ( )P 1 / 7exp XRD
According to Table 1, the porosity of the samples sintered under different atmospheres indicates an increase with sintering temperature. It is apparent that the material properties are dependent on the composition, preparation techniques and heat treatment conditions. F9 has larger porosity. It should be noted the porosity plays important role in control of physical properties of the polycrystalline ferrites. According to Table 1, the porosity of the samples sintered under different atmospheres shows an increase with sintering temperature because of increase in crystallite size and lattice parameter. Therefore, we conclude that the increase of porosity and the decrease of experimental density can be attributed to the increase of grain size due to their irregular shape.
Fig. 3 shows the IR spectra of F1–F9. The positions of two strong bands υ1 and υ2 about 570 cm 1 and 400 cm 1 are related to spinel cubic structure. The band υ1 is assigned to the vibrations of the bond between the tetrahedral metal ion and the oxygen ion Mtetra–O. Also, the band υ2 is assigned to the vibrations of the bond between the octahedral metal ion and the oxygen ion Mocta–O [6]. Therefore, the formation of spinel structure has been also confirmed by FTIR measurement as obtained from XRD result. The broadening is commonly observed in the inverse spinel ferrites caused by the statistical distribution of Fe3þ ions on A- and B-sites.
In the light of the above consideration and according to XRD results, the larger inversion for F1, F4, F7 can be observed as decrease in intensity or increase in broadening of the absorption band as shown in Fig. 3.
Table 2 shows the position of absorption bands as wave numbers. Looking at this Table, we can observe that the positions of tetrahedral and octahedral bands depend on sintering temperature and atmosphere. The lower frequency band can be assigned to higher deformation mode of M-O. The variation in the lattice constant can be explained by referring net effect of contraction and expansion of M–O bond length created in the A and B sites. Therefore, this variation in the band positions may be due to the variation in the cation-oxygen bond length observed in two sites as seen in lattice parameter. More contraction in lattice parameter of F7 with respect to F1 and F4 can be explained by the net effect of contraction and expansion of M–O bond length created in the A and B sites (see Table 2).
In addition to these strong bands, there is a weak band observed at 440 and 460 cm 1 around υ2 for F3 and F9 which is attributed to the presence of Jahn-Teller Fe4þ and Fe2þ ions, respectively (see Fig. 3). Non-cubic crystal field potential originated from these ions causes splitting of the frequency bands. The existence of Fe2þ ions is also observed in IR spectra around 470 cm 1 for sample Ni0.50Cu0.05Zn0.45Fe2O4 sintered at 1030 °C [3]. The band extended at 1600 cm 1 observed in IR spectra of F4 and F7 might correspond to stretching vibrations of H-O-H groups due to presence of remained water.
Different morphology is observed in SEM micrographs of F3, F6 and F9 as shown in Fig. 4. Presence of citric acid prevents agglomeration of the particles to a large extent. F9 and F3 show
highest and lowest porosity in accordance to the results of Table 1, respectively. TEM micrographs and particle size distribution of F7 are shown in Fig. 5a and b. The selected area electron diffraction (SAED) pattern is illustrated in the inset of Fig. 5a for F7 emphasizes the polynanocrystalline feature. Size distribution histogram is fitted by using a log-normal function as follows [23]:
σ π σ ( ) = − ( ) ⎪ ⎪ ⎧⎨ ⎩ ⎛ ⎝⎜ ⎞ ⎠⎟ ⎫⎬ ⎭D exp D D P d 1 2 1 2 ln 8d d TEM 2 2
where sd is the standard deviation of the diameter and DTEM is the mean diameter obtained from the TEM results. The calculated mean diameter of particle size DTEM is 13 nm.

sections.heading: 3.2. Magnetic measurements
sections.text:
The hysteresis loops of F1–F9, measured at 300 K are shown in Fig. 6. The S-shaped hysteresis loops show low coercivity field HC
(intersection with the axis x), low remanance magnetization Mr (intersection with the axis x) and a high saturation magnetization MS (obtained from low of approach to saturation). The low values of HC and Mr summarized in Tables 3 and 4 suggest a superparamagnetic behavior in the samples. The increase of HC with sintering temperature is the result of increase in magnetic domains.
The magnetization M versus the applied magnetic field, H, for the samples sintered at 600 °C can be properly fitted by keeping some terms of law of approach to saturation (Eq. 4) as follows:
( )( )( ) χ= − − + ( )⎡⎣ ⎤⎦M H M b H c H H1 / / 9s 2 3 However, in the case the samples sintered at 200 °C it is found
that the magnetization data do not exactly fit with the well-known law of Eq. (4). In fact, the high slope of the magnetization curves in the range of high magnetic fields seems to indicate the existence of a superparamagnetic behavior of the smaller ferromagnetic particles. If such contribution is taken into account, the law of approach to magnetic saturation must be expressed as:
( )( ) ( ) ( )= − + ( * − * ) ( ) ⎡⎣ ⎤⎦M H M b H M c H c H1 / coth 1 10 s f s sp, 2 ,
where Ms,f and Ms, sp are the contributions to the magnetization saturation of the ferromagnetic and super-paramagnetic phases, respectively. The best fit has been done for the samples as shown in Fig. 7 for F7 and F9. The fitting parameters of Eqs. (9) and (10) for the samples are summarized in Tables 3 and 4.
In the case of a cubic crystal structure, the coefficient b is given as follow [24]:
= ( )

where K1 is the cubic anisotropy constant of first order. The anisotropy constant K1 for F1, F3, F4, F6, F7 and F9 have been calculated by using Eq. 11 and the values of MS and b are obtained from Eq. (9) and (10). The results are summarized in Tables 3 and 4.
In addition, we evaluate the particle size distributions of F1–F9 through the analysis of magnetization curves and the results are compared with those estimated from TEM image and XRD analysis. For magnetic materials having super-paramagnetic behavior, the M–H curve is well fitted with the size distributed Langevin function [25]:

Fitting of M/MS curve versus H/T measured at 300 K for the samples was done with the size distributed Langevin function (12). The best fit has been done for the samples as shown for F7 and F9 in Fig. 8. The results of the magnetic core size are written in Tables 3 and 4. In this method, the average diameter of F7 is obtained as 10.01 nm and is in good agreement with the crystallite size estimated from Scherrer, H-W and TEM methods. This is related to the regular shape of nano-particles with spherical morphologies as observed in the TEM micrographs. Also, the magnetic diameter dmag smaller than DTEM reflects a thin magnetically dead layer on the surface of the nano-particles.
Looking at Tables 3 and 4, we can observe that the saturation magnetization increases with the sintering temperature and reaches a maximum 63 emu/g for F9. It is obvious that the number of the magnetic ions on the A and B sub-lattices and the resulting magnetic moment of the ferrites are affected by modification of ferrite composition with magnetic/diamagnetic ions [6,7]. Also, the resultant exchange interactions are dependent on the modified ionic distribution [3]. Here, the variation of saturation
/T) curves and particle size distribution used in the calculation for F7 and F9. Solid hich gives the best fit to experiments. dm, s and dmag are the statistical median, the
magnetization with sintering temperatures and atmospheres can be attributed to change of three factors: magnetic core size, inversion parameter and the change of Fe3þ-ion concentration due to the presence of Fe4þ and Fe2þ ions. Total magnetization of the ferrites could be expressed by Neel model as:
= − ( )M M M 16B A
where, MA and MB are magnetization in A and B sub-lattices, respectively. For F1, F4 and F7, the samples sintered at lower temperature, the magnetic core sizes are similar and there are no the presence of Fe4þ and Fe2þ ions. Therefore, the inversion phenomenon is the main factor for explaining variation of the saturation magnetization. According to the XRD results, this effect in F4 is much more than F7 and F1, respectively. At low sintering temperature, the inversion phenomenon increases due to higher formation of Fe3þ ions in the A site. Thus, the presence of the Fe3þ ions in the A sites and Zn2þ ions in the B sites leads to increase and decrease of the magnetic moments in the A and B sites, respectively. Consequently, according to Neel model (Eq. (16)), decrease in the net magnetic moment of F4 is more than F1 and F7.
For F3, F6 and F9, the samples sintered at higher temperature, it seems that the magnetic core size and the change of the Fe3þ-ion concentration are the main factors for explaining variation of saturation magnetization. Presence of Fe4þ (4μB) and Fe2þ (4μB) ions can cause reduction of saturation magnetization in F3 and F9, respectively. But, according to the results obtained from the XRD and FTIR measurements, the low Fe2þ and Fe4þ ions concentration in F3 and F9 suggest that the magnetic core size has the dominant effect in these samples.
The permeability can be expressed as μ¼1þχspinþχdw, wherein spin is the susceptibility due to spins and dw stands for susceptibility due to domain wall motion. In other words, the permeability is due to two contributions: the domain wall displacements and the magnetization rotation [26]. The domain wall motion and the spin rotation contributions vary linearly with square of magnetization saturation (MS) and inversely with the magneto-crystalline anisotropy (K1) of the ferrite. In addition, the domain wall motion contribution shows a linear relation with average grain size [26]. In this study, we consider that the value of K1 is similar for the samples, so this parameter does not affect the permeability. Therefore, the variation of permeability versus temperature is then only depends on the variations of Ms and the grain size. Considering Tables 3,4, we can observed that F9 has higher value of MS and the grain size (here dmag) with respect to the other samples sintered at 600 °C. These results suggest that F9 can present the good initial permeability.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusion
sections.text:
In this work, the structural and magnetic properties of Ni0.3Cu0.2Zn0.5Fe2O4 nano-particles prepared by citrate precursor method have been investigated. The effects of different sintering atmosphere and temperature on the redistribution of Zn2þ and Fe3þ ions, the oxidation of Fe atoms in lattice are studied. These studies have been performed by calculating crystallite sizes, lattice parameter, IR bands, saturation magnetization and magnetic core sizes. The results obtained are summarized as follow:
1. The structural characterization of the samples by X-ray powder diffraction and using X'Pert package and Fullprof program is evidence for a cubic structure (Fd-3m space group) for the samples. These results have been confirmed by FT-IR measurements. 2. Increasing trend of unit cell parameter and crystallite size with
temperature is observed in different sintering atmospheres that this is higher for the samples sintered under carbon monoxideambient atmosphere. 3. The increase of porosity and the decrease of experimental density observed in the samples sintered under different atmospheres can be attributed to the increase of grain size due to their irregular shape. Also, the sample sintered under carbon monoxide-ambient atmosphere at 600 °C shows good porosity. 4. The low values of HC and Mr of the samples suggest a superparamagnetic behavior in the samples. Also, the saturation magnetization increases with the sintering temperature and a maximum 63 emu/g is achieved for F9. The variation of saturation magnetization with sintering temperatures and atmospheres can be attributed to change of three factors: magnetic core size, inversion parameter and the change of Fe3þ-ion concentration due to the presence of Fe4þ and Fe2þ ions. The inversion phenomenon is the main factor for explaining variation of the saturation magnetization of the samples sintered at temperature 200 °C. But, according to the results obtained from the XRD and FTIR measurements for the samples sintered at 600 °C, the inversion and the Fe2þ and Fe4þ ions concentration in F3 and F9 are low. These suggest that the magnetic core size has the dominant effect in variation of the saturation magnetization of the samples. However, F9 can present good initial permeability due to higher MS and dmag with respect to the other samples that is more favorable for MLCC and MLCI applications.

metadata.abstractText: In this work, effects of sintering atmosphere and temperature on structural and magnetic properties of Ni0.3Cu0.2Zn0.5Fe2O4 nanoparticles prepared by citrate precursor method have been studied. The structural characterization of the samples by X-ray powder diffraction and FT-IR spectroscopy is evidence for formation of a cubic structure with no presence of impurity phase. Calculated values of crystallite size and unit cell parameter show an increase with sintering temperature under different atmospheres. Variation of saturation magnetization with sintering temperature and atmosphere can be attributed to change of three factors: magnetic core size, inversion parameter and the change of Fe3þ-ion concentration due to the presence of Fe4þ and Fe2þ ions. The saturation magnetization gradually grows with sintering temperature due to increase of magnetic core size and a maximum 63 emu/g was achieved at 600 °C under carbon monoxide-ambient atmosphere. & 2016 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
